A cool thing about this video and most of them is that it starts from something we all know, to guide us to to deeper science. On the other hand, I don't completely agree with calling Poisson's idea a "mistake". He may have been wrong in his assumption of light being particles(*), but that did not prevent him from drawing a correct and interesting conclusion, based on the assumption that it would be a wave. Thinking so hard about a competing theory is an accomplishment in itself. The only regret is that he didn't actually perform the experiment.

(*) was it actually wrong?: first of all, in those days, the debate particles/waves was unsolved, so he couldn't know. Secondly, light obviously also has a particle character, so he wasn't completely wrong after all.

There's something else that goes on with my vision that's similar to floaters (I have those too) in terms of the effect but what I actually see is like a static disturbance in the sky. It's only visible outdoors, and is most visible on bright but cloudy days by looking in the near distance above the horizon (ie it's contrast that can only be seen on a bright white background like a cloud). My hypotheses are that it's either small bugs darting around, pressure/ionic/water vapour disturbances or some other physical phenomenon, or it's some kind of optical illusion that is perceived but doesn't exist. I tend towards the former or latter because it appears to have life, indicated by different sizes of disturbances and interaction between but it's hard to study for any length of time because the brightness required to see them is usually quite uncomfortable. Maybe a bit tough to test without me really pointing out what I mean, and if it is bugs or a physical disturbance then we're so used to them and we have such differing eyesight capabilities that I've not yet been able to point them out to anyone. I don't think anything but the highest resolution professional quality cameras would be able to catch something of that detail at such an awkwardly vague focal length

There is a much simpler and more plausible explanation, in my eyes, of this so-called spot of Poisson.
A reflection telescope transmits an image of what is behind the primary, parabolic mirror. In this case, if light was shining on the back of a parabolic mirror, the image of the back of this external mirror, which is not part of the reflection telescope, would be transmitted to the primary mirror, which is part of the telescope. What happens to be transmitted is the light shining on the highest point of the back of the mirror.

The wave vs particle concepts was debated because people had a very rigid view of what waves are supposed to be. A wave is continuous, going up and down forever. The concept of short burst became clear when I worked with the ultrafast femtosecond laser MaiTai.


Each pulse is about 20 to 100 femtosecond. The frequency of that light is 1/800 nm = 375 THz


Each pulse had the time to oscillate about 100 times.


From that experience came the idea: what if one photon would be a single sinusoidal oscillation, like a wheel that makes a single turn, 360 degrees.


That is why light act like a particle. Each photon is only a one cycle wave.

It's still a double reflection. think of the conical shape of the light around the shadow reflecting back to the shiny ball. The light is dim and gets dispersed in all directions on the dark side of the ball. The brightest potential is found in the angle where the most light converges from the first reflection to the ball and back to the centre.

Clearly the author has never took college level physics. The light can only bend so far around a object. The bright spot is not always in the middle. I see more than one question in the comments about the Moon during a total solar eclipse. No, you won't see a faint spot of light in the center of the Moon. The spot is in the shadow of the Moon as cast upon the Earth (or a handy 3000-mile wide screen, just in case.)

What it would look like to puny Humans on the surface of Earth is: some people standing in the right place at the right time, see the Moon's rim outlined with light, a bit uneven (look up Bailey's Beads). Others not so located see the same thing, but the rim isn't quite as bright. In the first case, those people are standing in the Spot of Arago. The ones "not so located" are outside it, but still within the umbra of the shadow.

The difference may not be noticeable to casual observation, and besides, the Sun is about 1/2° diameter, not a coherent point source, so I'm not sure there's much of a Spot of Arago anyway. Maybe someone not as lazy as I could do a calculation...

Nice demo!  What does this have to do with real life? Some may be wondering.  The "spot of Arago" is a big problem for one astronomy experiment - the Starshade.  The idea is to block the light of one star with a big disk, so a telescope can pick up a faint  planet next to it.  The scientist who came up with it, Dr. Webster Cash, found a way to make the spot vanish.  The disk has tapered tips around the edge, like a weird daisy designed by an engineer.  Now, go explain why that works...

I don't know if anyone has made this comment in the 2419 comments already written below, but Richard Feynman has lectures on YouTube where he clearly explains that light is a particle and NOT a wave.  It has wave-like properties that are more easily explained by treating it as a wave such phenomena as diffusion and interference, but the reality of it all is that light is a particle...photons.  Period.  It is not a wave.  It is a particle.  When you try to explain what gives rise to these strange interference/diffusion patterns, it gets complicated, but Feyman's genius is in the way he can simplify it so that you can understand that yes, light IS a particle and NOT a wave.  Search for QED, Feynman to find his series on light reflection/interference.  Your brain might explode from how awesome it is, but again, light is NOT a wave.  It is a particle. This wave-particle duality of light is one of the most mistaught ideas in physics.  I've been telling my students for 25 years that light is a wave and a particle.  But now that I know better, I will word it properly: Light is a particle, but some of it's behaviors can more easily be explained as if it were a wave, but it's not a wave.  It is a particle.  Period.  End of story.

So Veritasium, I have made an experiment a few weeks ago on the 19th Oct that you may be interested in, it is the production of diffraction pattern similar to the single slit experiment but using a single point diffractive source, and in my case I used an ordinary paper staple:

The top microsoft paint image is a sketch of the apparatus.
The bottom image is what happened if I encircled the staple almost perfectly by the staple. I'm rather fascinated by this because it didn't made much of a diffraction pattern despite the light being almost completely enveloped by the staple, though unfortunately that was not the goal of my customised experiment.
All other images were the actual experiment. A grid sheet of 1x1mm (main lines 1x1cm) squares is provided on one of the images, and the screen to staple length was one meter.

you are taking the analogy too far when you state that light is a wave. a wave is kinetic energy moving through a medium<stuff is moving. light is energy being conducted through a medium<nothing moving just an exchange of charge between particles. the two are similar enough to make the analogy work but only in this aspect of its behavior when you get to HOW the charge moves you run in to a particle analogy in that a photon has a minimum unit size. but this analogy is just as narrow as the other. the fact is that a photon is neither a particle or a wave we just use those analogies to visualize something we cant actually see. quantum mechanics as near as i can tell says that the light you see is the portion of light whose random path from particle to particle averaged out to a straight line from the source to your eye or whose path was reflected from an object to your eye.  the path is an average because the actual path is a random zigzag.<no particle just the charge ..or if there is a charge carrier of some sort moving it only "moves" to the next particle. there are no photons "traveling" from the sun to the earth nor bouncing off objects just charges interacting with and being re emitted in random directions by particles some of which by pure chance happen to enter your eye and impart information.

When you talk about the light having to be coherent, you actually mean spatially coherent. It doesn't need to be temporally coherent (since it can be done with many frequencies at the same time), so I wanted to point that out when you referred to coherence. Spatially coherent light can easily be made from any incoherent light source, however I have some comments to make about the way you tried making it with the beamer. You see, beamers work in a very specific way, namely by a set of mirrors that can reflect light very quickly for different colors to build a RGB image. However I think this construction of how the beamer builds it's image is actually bad for trying to make nice planar waves, I hypothesize that you in fact get many disruptions in your nice plane wave because of this, this might have foiled your attempt. Also, the projector try, you didn't even try to make it spatially coherent as far as I could tell from the video, so obviously it didn't work. You can make a spatially coherent source easily with a candle and a single slit/hole for example, which is probably how they did it back then.

Great video, as always! Now I have a paradox for you. Maybe you've heard it before, but it's interesting nonetheless. Here's how it goes: You have three spaceships, A, B, and C, all pointed in the same direction and all weighing 2kg (to simplify the math). Spaceship A is stationary, and spaceships B and C are moving at a constant speed of 1 m/s. Spaceship B then accelerates to 2 m/s and holds a constant speed. We're interested in calculating the energy it took to accelerate from 1 m/s to 2 m/s. First, let's say we're observing from spaceship A. We see spaceship B accelerate from 1 m/s to 2 m/s, so from the equation KE = 1/2 mv^2, we have a change in kinetic energy of 3 J. Next, let's say we're observing from spaceship C. Since we're moving at a constant velocity, spaceship C is a Newtonian reference frame. Thus, we observe spaceship B accelerate from 0 m/s to 1 m/s, giving a change in kinetic energy of 1 J. This gives us two largely different values for the amount of energy used. So the question is: how is this resolved? The solution involves a more in-depth analysis using conservation of momentum, but it makes you think twice about using kinematic equations without checking the result.
